elements.content: Two multidentate ligands containing a delocalized π-electron system, 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-3-yl)-ethenyl]­cyclohex-2-enylidene}­propanedinitrile (L1) and 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-2-yl)-ethenyl]­cyclohex-2-enylidene}­propanedinitrile (L2), were synthesized. By self-assembly of the ligands with silver­(I) salts, six supramolecular complexes, [Ag­(L1)­(TsO)­(H2O)]2 (1), {[Ag3(L1)2(H2O)]­(ClO4)3} n (2), {[Ag­(L1)­(NO3)]·0.5C6H6} n (3), {[Ag­(L2)­(NO3)]·0.5C6H6} n (4), [Ag­(L2)2]­(ClO4) (5), and [Ag­(L2)2]­(PF6) (6), with different structures and topologies were obtained. In polymer 2, L1 acts as a tridentate ligand to bind Ag­(I) ions to form a one-dimensional (1D) supramolecular structure. However, when the ligands adopt bidentate coordination modes to coordinate with Ag­(I) ions through the pyridyl nitrogen atom and one cyano nitrogen atom, the dinuclear supramolecular complex 1, 1D coordination polymer 3, and two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer 4 were obtained. In 5 or 6, only the pyridyl nitrogen atom of L2 ligand coordinates with the Ag­(I) ion to form a mononuclear complex. The multiple coordination modes of the multidentate ligands and the effect of anions and solvents play important roles in the structural and topological diversity. The luminescent properties were investigated. Compared with the ligands, the complexes show superior luminescent properties with red-shifted and enhanced emission as well as longer fluorescence lifetimes, which indicates that they may be good candidates for optical materials.

In polymer 2, L1 acts as a tridentate ligand to bind Ag(I) ions to form a one-dimensional (1D) supramolecular structure. However, when the ligands adopt bidentate coordination modes to coordinate with Ag(I) ions through the pyridyl nitrogen atom and one cyano nitrogen atom, the dinuclear supramolecular complex 1, 1D coordination polymer 3, and two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer 4 were obtained. In 5 or 6, only the pyridyl nitrogen atom of L2 ligand coordinates with the Ag(I) ion to form a mononuclear complex. The multiple coordination modes of the multidentate ligands and the effect of anions and solvents play important roles in the structural and topological diversity. The luminescent properties were investigated. Compared with the ligands, the complexes show superior luminescent properties with red-shifted and enhanced emission as well as longer fluorescence lifetimes, which indicates that they may be good candidates for optical materials.

elements.content: A series of different structural Ag­(I) supramolecular complexes were synthesized by self-assembly of two novel π-conjugated multidentate ligands with silver­(I) salts. The crystal structures and luminescent properties of all compounds were investigated. Compared with the corresponding ligand, the complexes show superior luminescent properties with red-shifted and enhanced emission as well as longer fluorescence lifetimes.
elements.clean_text: A series of different structural Ag(I) supramolecular complexes were synthesized by self-assembly of two novel π-conjugated multidentate ligands with silver(I) salts. The crystal structures and luminescent properties of all compounds were investigated. Compared with the corresponding ligand, the complexes show superior luminescent properties with red-shifted and enhanced emission as well as longer fluorescence lifetimes.

elements.content: In recent years, the design and synthesis of supramolecular complexes have become one of the most active fields in coordination chemistry and crystal engineering due to not only their novel topologies and fascinating structural diversities but also their special chemical and physical properties as well as their potential applications as functional materials. The simple association of ligand with metal salt through the coordination and noncovalent interactions can be used to assemble new coordination complexes exhibiting properties that are not displayed by either of the components alone. Up to now, a number of supramolecular complexes with specific topologies and excellent properties have been synthesized by assembly of metal salts and organic ligands. Obviously, the motivation of complexes research is to control the structures of the target products, to investigate the structure–property relationships and elucidate the principles that guide molecular assembly, and thereby, to create novel functional valuable materials with excellent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the design and synthesis of supramolecular complexes have become one of the most active fields in coordination chemistry and crystal engineering due to not only their novel topologies and fascinating structural diversities but also their special chemical and physical properties as well as their potential applications as functional materials. The simple association of ligand with metal salt through the coordination and noncovalent interactions can be used to assemble new coordination complexes exhibiting properties that are not displayed by either of the components alone. Up to now, a number of supramolecular complexes with specific topologies and excellent properties have been synthesized by assembly of metal salts and organic ligands. Obviously, the motivation of complexes research is to control the structures of the target products, to investigate the structure-property relationships and elucidate the principles that guide molecular assembly, and thereby, to create novel functional valuable materials with excellent properties.

elements.content: In design and synthesis of supramolecular complexes with intriguing structures and excellent optical properties, the multidentate π-conjugated ligands have been most extensively used due to their good optical properties and their ability to coordinate to metal centers in various modes. And it is more important that metal–organic complexes have abilities to affect the emission wavelength and intensity of the organic material through metal coordination. The incorporation of metal ion often increases the conformational rigidity of ligand and reduces the loss of energy via intramolecular vibrational and rotational motions. As a result, the improvement of optical properties of organic ligands may be achieved. Therefore, design and synthesis of suitable multidentate π-conjugated organic ligands are critical factors in construction of metal–organic coordination complexes with fascinating structures and excellent optical properties. In order to construct novel supramolecular complexes with specific structures and properties, two multidentate ligands containing a π-conjugated system and the pyridyl as well as dicyanoisophorone groups, namely, 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-3-yl)-ethenyl]­cyclohex-2-enylidene}­propanedinitrile (L1) and 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-2-yl)-ethenyl]­cyclohex-2-enylidene}­propanedinitrile (L2) were synthesized. In the ligands, the isophorone moiety was chosen as a conjugation bridge of the terminal pyridyl and dicyano groups. One reason is that polyene-based organic compound possesses a larger dipole moment and polarizability anisotropy than an aromatic ring. When the pyridyl and dicyano groups are incorporated at both ends of the isophorone conjugation bridge, the extensive charge transfer is able to occur along a π-conjugated bridge, which is expected to endow excellent optical properties. The other is that the isophorone structure provides another advantage that the steric hindrance associated with the ring structure as well as the dimethyl substituents of an isophorone unit is expected to hinder the formation of intermolecular π···π interactions, which may effectively avoid fluorescence quenching of complex in the solid state.

And it is more important that metal-organic complexes have abilities to affect the emission wavelength and intensity of the organic material through metal coordination. The incorporation of metal ion often increases the conformational rigidity of ligand and reduces the loss of energy via intramolecular vibrational and rotational motions. As a result, the improvement of optical properties of organic ligands may be achieved. Therefore, design and synthesis of suitable multidentate π-conjugated organic ligands are critical factors in construction of metal-organic coordination complexes with fascinating structures and excellent optical properties. In order to construct novel supramolecular complexes with specific structures and properties, two multidentate ligands containing a π-conjugated system and the pyridyl as well as dicyanoisophorone groups, namely, 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-3-yl)-ethenyl]cyclohex-2-enylidene}propanedinitrile (L1) and 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-2-yl)-ethenyl]cyclohex-2-enylidene}propanedinitrile (L2) were synthesized. In the ligands, the isophorone moiety was chosen as a conjugation bridge of the terminal pyridyl and dicyano groups. One reason is that polyene-based organic compound possesses a larger dipole moment and polarizability anisotropy than an aromatic ring. When the pyridyl and dicyano groups are incorporated at both ends of the isophorone conjugation bridge, the extensive charge transfer is able to occur along a π-conjugated bridge, which is expected to endow excellent optical properties. The other is that the isophorone structure provides another advantage that the steric hindrance associated with the ring structure as well as the dimethyl substituents of an isophorone unit is expected to hinder the formation of intermolecular π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, which may effectively avoid fluorescence quenching of complex in the solid state.

elements.content: Considering the nitrile functional group easily coordinates with the silver­(I) ion, and silver­(I) has various coordination modes, whose coordination numbers can vary from two to eight, self-assembly of the ligands with silver­(I) salts was carried out. The ligands adopt different coordination modes with the cyano and pyridyl groups to construct diverse structural supramolecular complexes, [Ag­(L1)­(TsO)­(H2O)]2 (1), {[Ag3(L1)2(H2O)]­(ClO4)3} n (2), {[Ag­(L1)­(NO3)]·0.5C6H6} n (3), {[Ag­(L2)­(NO3)]·0.5C6H6} n (4), [Ag­(L2)2]­(ClO4) (5), and [Ag­(L2)2]­(PF6) (6). The crystal structures and solid state luminescent properties were investigated in detail. The results show that the complexes show superior luminescent properties with red-shifted and enhanced emission as well as longer fluorescence lifetimes compared with the corresponding free ligand.

elements.clean_text: 1  Organic Ligands Used in the Construction of the Complexes

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals are of analytical grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out on Perkin-Elmer 240 analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV 400 spectrometer with TMS as internal standard. The mass spectra were obtained on a Micromass GCT-MS spectrometer. IR spectra were recorded from KBr discs in the 4000–40 cm–1 range on a nicolet Nexus 870 spectrophotometer. The solid state luminescence spectra were measured on F-4500 FL spectrophotometer. In the measurements of emission and excitation spectra, the pass width is 5 nm for all compounds. For time-resolved fluorescence measurements, the fluorescence signals were collimated and focused onto the entrance slit of a monochromator with the output plane equipped with a photomultiplier tube (HORIBA HuoroMax-4P). The decays were analyzed by least-squares. The quality of the exponential fits was evaluated by the goodness of fit (χ2).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All commercially available chemicals are of analytical grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out on Perkin-Elmer 240 analyzer. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV 400 spectrometer with TMS as internal standard. The mass spectra were obtained on a Micromass GCT-MS spectrometer. IR spectra were recorded from KBr discs in the 4000-40 cm-1 range on a nicolet Nexus 870 spectrophotometer. The solid state luminescence spectra were measured on F-4500 FL spectrophotometer. In the measurements of emission and excitation spectra, the pass width is 5 nm for all compounds. For time-resolved fluorescence measurements, the fluorescence signals were collimated and focused onto the entrance slit of a monochromator with the output plane equipped with a photomultiplier tube (HORIBA HuoroMax-4P). The decays were analyzed by least-squares. The quality of the exponential fits was evaluated by the goodness of fit (χ2).

elements.content: All complexes were prepared by a similar procedure. A clear benzene solution (10 mL) of the silver salt AgX (1 mmol, X = TsO (1), ClO4 – (2 and 5), NO3 – (3 and 4), PF6 – (6)) was carefully layered onto a solution of L1 or L2 (0.276 g, 1 mmol) in dichloromethane (15 mL). Single crystals of 1–6 suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were obtained by slow interlayer diffusion.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of Silver(I) Complexes

All complexes were prepared by a similar procedure. A clear benzene solution (10 mL) of the silver salt AgX (1 mmol, X = TsO (1), ClO4 - (2 and 5), NO3 - (3 and 4), PF6 - (6)) was carefully layered onto a solution of L1 or L2 (0.276 g, 1 mmol) in dichloromethane (15 mL). Single crystals of 1-6 suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were obtained by slow interlayer diffusion.

The X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a Bruker SMART CCD area detector using graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å) at 298 (2) K. Intensity data were collected in the variable ω-scan mode. The structures were solved by direct methods and difference Fourier syntheses. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were introduced geometrically. Calculations were performed with SHELXTL-97 program package. CCDC−909295 (for complex 1), −909070 (for complex 2), −886434 (for complex 3), −914884 (for complex 4), −889145 (for complex 5) and −875482 (for complex 6) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Details of the crystal parameters, data collections and refinements are listed in Table , and selected bond distances and angles are given in Table S2, .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Refinement

The X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a Bruker SMART CCD area detector using graphite monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å) at 298 (2) K. Intensity data were collected in the variable ω-scan mode. The structures were solved by direct methods and difference Fourier syntheses. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were introduced geometrically. Calculations were performed with SHELXTL-97 program package. CCDC-909295 (for complex 1), -909070 (for complex 2), -886434 (for complex 3), -914884 (for complex 4), -889145 (for complex 5) and -875482 (for complex 6) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Details of the crystal parameters, data collections and refinements are listed in Table , and selected bond distances and angles are given in Table S2, .

The synthetic procedure of the ligands is shown in Scheme S1, . The ligands can be easily prepared, according to a procedure similar to that reported earlier. The intermediate 2-(3,5,5-trimethylcyclohex-2-enylidene)­malononitrile was synthesized according to the literature method with a high yield of 95%. Details of syntheses of L1 and L2 are described in . The 1H NMR spectra of ligands agree well with their structures and display 17 proton resonances for them. As shown in Scheme , L1 and L2 are multidentate unsymmetric ligands and contain three terminal coordination sites, that is, one pyridyl and two −CN groups, which may completely or partially coordinate with silver­(I) ion to construct different structural complexes. In addition, the ligands are easily soluble in common organic solvents, such as CH2Cl2 and CHCl3, which potentially facilitates the solution reaction between the ligands and inorganic salts. Complexes 1–6 were obtained in a benzene and dichloromethane mixed solvent system by self-assembly of ligands with Ag­(I) salts at room temperature. It is worth noting that, under the same experimental conditions, the products do not depend on the ligand-to-metal ratio. However, increasing the metal-to-ligand ratio resulted in somewhat higher yield and higher crystal quality. All crystals are air stable and photostable, and can retain their structural integrity at room temperature for a considerable length of time. In the IR spectra of ligands and all complexes, the intense ν­(−CN) stretching bands of cyanogroups are easily identified at 2219 (L1), 2216 (1), 2252 (2), 2220 (3), 2218 (L2), 2249/2219 (4), 2254/2221 (5) and 2217 (6) cm–1. Compared with that of the corresponding free ligand, the stretching bands of cyanogroups in the complexes either show significant upshift or become broader or split into two peaks. The difference obviously caused by the coordination taken place along the −CN direction with formation of δ bond with Ag­(I) or the weak interaction based on the cyanogroups. The facts agree well with the results of complexes 1–6 determined by X-ray single crystal diffraction. In addition, the characteristic bands of the anions in different complexes can be assigned easily. The IR data are shown in Table S1, .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Characterization

The synthetic procedure of the ligands is shown in Scheme S1, . The ligands can be easily prepared, according to a procedure similar to that reported earlier. The intermediate 2-(3,5,5-trimethylcyclohex-2-enylidene)malononitrile was synthesized according to the literature method with a high yield of 95%. Details of syntheses of L1 and L2 are described in . The 1H NMR spectra of ligands agree well with their structures and display 17 proton resonances for them. As shown in Scheme , L1 and L2 are multidentate unsymmetric ligands and contain three terminal coordination sites, that is, one pyridyl and two -CN groups, which may completely or partially coordinate with silver(I) ion to construct different structural complexes. In addition, the ligands are easily soluble in common organic solvents, such as CH2Cl2 and CHCl3, which potentially facilitates the solution reaction between the ligands and inorganic salts. Complexes 1-6 were obtained in a benzene and dichloromethane mixed solvent system by self-assembly of ligands with Ag(I) salts at room temperature. It is worth noting that, under the same experimental conditions, the products do not depend on the ligand-to-metal ratio. However, increasing the metal-to-ligand ratio resulted in somewhat higher yield and higher crystal quality. All crystals are air stable and photostable, and can retain their structural integrity at room temperature for a considerable length of time. In the IR spectra of ligands and all complexes, the intense ν(-CN) stretching bands of cyanogroups are easily identified at 2219 (L1), 2216 (1), 2252 (2), 2220 (3), 2218 (L2), 2249/2219 (4), 2254/2221 (5) and 2217 (6) cm-1. Compared with that of the corresponding free ligand, the stretching bands of cyanogroups in the complexes either show significant upshift or become broader or split into two peaks. The difference obviously caused by the coordination taken place along the -CN direction with formation of δ bond with Ag(I) or the weak interaction based on the cyanogroups. The facts agree well with the results of complexes 1-6 determined by X-ray single crystal diffraction. In addition, the characteristic bands of the anions in different complexes can be assigned easily. The IR data are shown in Table S1, .

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P1̅. As shown in Figure a, L1 adopts the cis-conformation to bind Ag­(I) ions with pyridyl and cyano moieties located the same side of ligand. Two ligands in a head-to-tail mode bridge two Ag­(I) ions via the N atoms of the pyridyl and −CN to generate a 24-numbered binuclear metallomacrocycle with the Ag···Ag distance of 7.161 Å. The Ag­(I) center is four coordinated by two oxygen atoms from H2O and TsO–, one pyridyl nitrogen atom from one ligand, and one −CN nitrogen atom from the other ligand, to form a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The Ag–N and Ag–O bond lengths (Table S2, ) fall within the normal range. The bond angles around the silver atom are in the range of 81.9 (1)–147.6(1)°.

Crystal Structure of [Ag(L1)(TsO)(H2O)]2 (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P1̅. As shown in Figure a, L1 adopts the cis-conformation to bind Ag(I) ions with pyridyl and cyano moieties located the same side of ligand. Two ligands in a head-to-tail mode bridge two Ag(I) ions via the N atoms of the pyridyl and -CN to generate a 24-numbered binuclear metallomacrocycle with the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance of 7.161 Å. The Ag(I) center is four coordinated by two oxygen atoms from H2O and TsO-, one pyridyl nitrogen atom from one ligand, and one -CN nitrogen atom from the other ligand, to form a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The Ag-N and Ag-O bond lengths (Table S2, ) fall within the normal range. The bond angles around the silver atom are in the range of 81.9 (1)-147.6(1)°.

elements.content: In the crystal packing of complex 1, the TsO– ions play a critical role in determining the final supramolecular structure due to multiple weak noncovalent forces formed by them. The adjacent dinuclear [Ag­(L1)­(TsO)­(H2O)]2 metallacycles are linked together in a staircase arrangement through the intermolecular hydrogen bonding C2–H2···O3 based on TsO– anions to form an infinite chain, as illustrated in Figure b. The chains are further connected via C4–H4···O3 hydrogen bonding and C14–H14B···π (phenyl ring of TsO–) interactions with H14B···centroid distance of 3.057 Å to generate a 2D supramolecular structure (Figure c). The H2···O3 and H4···O3 distances are 2.708(4) and 2.526(3) Å, respectively. The C2···O3 and C4···O3 distances are 3.383(6) and 3.419(5) Å, respectively. The corresponding C2–H2···O3 and C4–H4···O3 angles are 130.1 and 160.7°, respectively. The data fall within the normal range. The existence of weak C–H···X hydrogen bonding interactions is a central feature of the structures in these complexes, such as the C–H···O interactions in complex 1, C–H···N interactions in complexes 3, 4, and 5 as well as C–H···F interactions in complex 6. These hydrogen bonds, although weak, contribute significantly to the structural organization of complexes in the crystalline state.

The chains are further connected via C4-H4⋅⋅⋅O3 hydrogen bonding and C14-H14B⋅⋅⋅π (phenyl ring of TsO-) interactions with H14B⋅⋅⋅centroid distance of 3.057 Å to generate a 2D supramolecular structure (Figure c). The H2⋅⋅⋅O3 and H4⋅⋅⋅O3 distances are 2.708(4) and 2.526(3) Å, respectively. The C2⋅⋅⋅O3 and C4⋅⋅⋅O3 distances are 3.383(6) and 3.419(5) Å, respectively. elements.content: Single-crystal analysis indicates that 2 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P1̅. As shown in Figure a, it is a 1D coordination polymer with three silver­(I) ions in the asymmetric unit. A pair of ligands bridge two silver­(I) ions in a head-to-tail mode through Ag–N coordination bonds to generate a dinuclear [Ag2(L1)2]2+ metallacycle unit with the Ag···Ag distance of 8.512 Å. Ag2 ion exhibits approximate linear N2-coordination geometry coordinated by a cyano nitrogen atom from one ligand and a pyridyl nitrogen atom from the other ligand. At the same time, Ag1 ion shows tetragonal planar O2N2-coordination geometry coordinated by nitrogen atoms of cyanogroups and oxygen atoms from H2O molecules and thus bridges the two neighboring [Ag2(L1)2]2+ metallacycle units forming an infinite chain through Ag1–N1 bond. The Ag–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.145(4)–2.189(4) Å, and the Ag–O bond length is 2.592(6) Å, falling within the normal range. Furthermore, Ag­(I) cations in 2 are charge balanced by the perchlorate anions, and Ag2 weakly interacts with the oxygen atoms of ClO4 –. The N2–Ag2–N3 angle is not 180.00° but 167.0(2)°, which should be due to the influence of the weak Ag···O interactions.

At the same time, Ag1 ion shows tetragonal planar O2N2-coordination geometry coordinated by nitrogen atoms of cyanogroups and oxygen atoms from H2O molecules and thus bridges the two neighboring [Ag2(L1)2]2+ metallacycle units forming an infinite chain through Ag1-N1 bond. The Ag-N bond lengths are in the range of 2.145(4)-2.189(4) Å, and the Ag-O bond length is 2.592(6) Å, falling within the normal range. Furthermore, Ag(I) cations in 2 are charge balanced by the perchlorate anions, and Ag2 weakly interacts with the oxygen atoms of ClO4 -. elements.content: In the crystal structure of 2, the weak Ag···O interactions based on H2O play essential roles in generating the 2D supramolecular structure. As shown in Figure b, the chains are further connected by H2O through weak Ag2···O1 interactions with the distance of 2.713 Å to generate a sheet. Interestingly, in the 2D structure, the Ag­(I) nodes are connected via cyano groups and water molecules through Ag1–N1, Ag2–N2, Ag1–O1, and Ag2···O1 interactions, forming crossed double-chain along the a axis (Figure S2, ).

elements.content: Single-crystal analysis revealed that 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group C2/c. As shown in Figure a, it is a 1D coordination polymer with two different coordination geometry silver­(I) ions in the asymmetric unit. The ligand also adopts cis-conformation to bind the Ag­(I) ions through the pyridyl and cyano moieties located the same side of the ligand. Ag1 ion shows linear N2-coordination geometry coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms derived from two ligands. However, Ag2 ion exhibits distorted tetrahedral environment and is coordinated by two −CN nitrogen atoms derived from two ligands and two oxygen atoms from two NO3 – anions. The bond lengths and angles about silver­(I) ions are shown in Table S1, . Each ligand bridges Ag1 and Ag2 ions alternately in head-to-head and tail-to-tail modes, respectively, through Ag–N coordination bonds to generate an infinite zigzag chain along the crystallographic c axis.

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 3, the coordinated and uncoordinated −CN nitrogen atoms play essential roles in generating the 2D supramolecular structure through C–H···N hydrogen bonding interactions. As shown in Figure b, the neighboring chains are connected by C3–H3···N3 and C2–H2···N2 hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 2D supramolecular structure. The H3···N3 and H2···N2 distances are 2.744(4) and 2.640(3) Å, respectively. The C3···N3 and C2···N2 distances are 3.393(5) and 3.419(5) Å, respectively. The corresponding C3–H3···N3 and C2–H2···N2 angles are 127.6 and 151.9°, respectively. The existence and structural importance of hydrogen bonding interactions generated from −CN are now well-established and observed in many compounds. It is no doubt for these hydrogen bonding interactions to contribute significantly to the alignment of the molecules in the crystalline state. Solvent benzene molecules dispersed in the supramolecular structure. Benzene molecules were omitted for clarity because no weak interaction involving them was observed in the solid state of 3.

elements.content: Polymer 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P21/c. In contrast to the 1D chain structure of polymer 3, the polymeric structure of complex 4 is a 2D network. As shown in Figure a, the Ag­(I) center shows distorted tetrahedral O2N2-coordination geometry coordinated by two O1 atoms derived from two NO3 – anions, one pyridyl nitrogen atom, and one −CN nitrogen atom from two ligands. The Ag–O1, Ag–N1, and Ag–N3 bonding distances are 2.530(3), 2.218(3), and 2.194(3) Å, respectively. A pair of NO3 – ions as O-bridges link two Ag­(I) centers through Ag–O1 bonds generating a [Ag2O2] bimetallic rhombic unit. The Ag···Ag distance is 4.386 Å, which is longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii of two silver atoms, 3.44 Å. Each [Ag2O2] moiety, serving as a node, links with four neighboring [Ag2O2] nodes through L2 in trans-conformation to generate a 2D grid supramolecular structure as shown in Figure b.

elements.content: Complex 6 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P21/c. Similar to 5, complex 6 is also a mononuclear complex, the −CN groups do not directly involve coordination. The Ag­(I) center exhibits approximate linear N2-coordination geometry coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms derived from two L2 ligands with the Ag–N1 and Ag–N2 bonding distances of 2.180(4) and 2.182(4) Å, respectively. The N1–Ag–N2 bond angle is 162.5(1)°. The −CN nitrogen atom N6 from a neighboring molecule weakly interacts with Ag­(I) ion with a Ag···N6 distance of 2.961 Å. Through the weak Ag···N6 interactions, the mononuclear molecules are linked to form a zigzag chain as shown in Figure a. The zigzag supramolecular structures are connected each other through weak Ag···N3 interactions with distance of 2.953 Å to generate a 2D structure, as displayed in Figure b. The adjacent layers are stacked through C17–H17B···N4 hydrogen bonding interactions to form a double sheet (Figure S2, ). Multiple C–H···F hydrogen bonding interactions based on the uncoordinated PF6 – counterions are formed. The PF6 – anions are sandwiched by two adjacent double sheets, and in turn link the sheets together through the multiple C–H···F hydrogen bonding interactions (F···H distances in the range of 2.388–2.612 Å) to generate a 3D supramolecular structure.

Complex 6 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P21/c. Similar to 5, complex 6 is also a mononuclear complex, the -CN groups do not directly involve coordination. The Ag(I) center exhibits approximate linear N2-coordination geometry coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms derived from two L2 ligands with the Ag-N1 and Ag-N2 bonding distances of 2.180(4) and 2.182(4) Å, respectively. The N1-Ag-N2 bond angle is 162.5(1)°. The -CN nitrogen atom N6 from a neighboring molecule weakly interacts with Ag(I) ion with a Ag⋅⋅⋅N6 distance of 2.961 Å. Through the weak Ag⋅⋅⋅N6 interactions, the mononuclear molecules are linked to form a zigzag chain as shown in Figure a. The zigzag supramolecular structures are connected each other through weak Ag⋅⋅⋅N3 interactions with distance of 2.953 Å to generate a 2D structure, as displayed in Figure b. The adjacent layers are stacked through C17-H17B⋅⋅⋅N4 hydrogen bonding interactions to form a double sheet (Figure S2, ). Multiple C-H⋅⋅⋅F hydrogen bonding interactions based on the uncoordinated PF6 - counterions are formed. The PF6 - anions are sandwiched by two adjacent double sheets, and in turn link the sheets together through the multiple C-H⋅⋅⋅F hydrogen bonding interactions (F⋅⋅⋅H distances in the range of 2.388-2.612 Å) to generate a 3D supramolecular structure.

elements.content: In general, self-assembly of the multidentate ligands L1 and L2 with silver­(I) salts results in diverse structural supramolecular complexes. The multiple coordination modes of the ligands lead to the structure diversity. In polymer 2, L1 acts as a tridentate ligand to bind Ag­(I) ions to form dinuclear metallacycle contained 1D polymer. The ligands in 1, 3, and 4 adopt bidentate coordination modes to coordinate with Ag­(I) ions by the pyridyl nitrogen atom and one of −CN nitrogen atoms to generate dinuclear 0D (for 1), zigzag 1D (for 3) and 2D (for 4) supramolecular structures. However, in 5 or 6, only the pyridyl nitrogen atom of L2 ligand coordinates with Ag­(I) ion to form mononuclear complex. Notably, when it acts as a bidentate ligand, such as in complexes 1 and 3, L1 ligand easily adopts a cis-conformation of the pyridyl and cyanogroup nitrogen atoms, which locate on the same side of the ligand, to bind Ag­(I) atoms. However, in polymer 4, L2 ligand adopts trans-conformation of the pyridyl and cyano group nitrogen atoms to bind Ag­(I) atoms. The result may be caused by the steric hindrance effect of the dimethyl substituents of an isophorone unit and the pyridyl nitrogen position. It is worth noting that, as expected, because of the steric hindrance effect of the ring structure and the dimethyl substituents of an isophorone, no π···π interactions based on ligands were observed in all complexes, which would have significant influences on the solid state emission property of the crystals. It is well-known that the tight molecular packing in the crystalline state usually leads to significant molecular interactions and quenching of fluorescence emission. The most obvious way to restore the fluorescence is to prevent the molecular packing or the π···π stacking. Therefore, the absence of π···π stacking interactions may be one cause of the superior luminescent properties of all complexes in the solid states at ambient temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Comparison and Effect of Ligands and Anions on the Structures

In general, self-assembly of the multidentate ligands L1 and L2 with silver(I) salts results in diverse structural supramolecular complexes. The multiple coordination modes of the ligands lead to the structure diversity. In polymer 2, L1 acts as a tridentate ligand to bind Ag(I) ions to form dinuclear metallacycle contained 1D polymer. The ligands in 1, 3, and 4 adopt bidentate coordination modes to coordinate with Ag(I) ions by the pyridyl nitrogen atom and one of -CN nitrogen atoms to generate dinuclear 0D (for 1), zigzag 1D (for 3) and 2D (for 4) supramolecular structures. However, in 5 or 6, only the pyridyl nitrogen atom of L2 ligand coordinates with Ag(I) ion to form mononuclear complex. Notably, when it acts as a bidentate ligand, such as in complexes 1 and 3, L1 ligand easily adopts a cis-conformation of the pyridyl and cyanogroup nitrogen atoms, which locate on the same side of the ligand, to bind Ag(I) atoms. However, in polymer 4, L2 ligand adopts trans-conformation of the pyridyl and cyano group nitrogen atoms to bind Ag(I) atoms. The result may be caused by the steric hindrance effect of the dimethyl substituents of an isophorone unit and the pyridyl nitrogen position. It is worth noting that, as expected, because of the steric hindrance effect of the ring structure and the dimethyl substituents of an isophorone, no π⋅⋅⋅π interactions based on ligands were observed in all complexes, which would have significant influences on the solid state emission property of the crystals. It is well-known that the tight molecular packing in the crystalline state usually leads to significant molecular interactions and quenching of fluorescence emission. The most obvious way to restore the fluorescence is to prevent the molecular packing or the π⋅⋅⋅π stacking. Therefore, the absence of π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions may be one cause of the superior luminescent properties of all complexes in the solid states at ambient temperature.

elements.content: Additionally, the different anions (TsO–, ClO4 –, PF6 –, and NO3 –) also play important roles in the formation of the diverse structures of the complexes. The difference in the coordinating ability, size, geometric shape, symmetry and hydrogen-bonding ability of anions is the underlying reason behind the differences in the structures of complexes. In complex 1, Ag­(I) ions adopt distorted O2N2-coordination geometry. The TsO– anion, having strong coordinating ability, is involved in the coordinative interactions. At the same time, it also contributes to the formation of a higher-dimensional structure through the hydrogen bonding and C–H···π interactions based on it. However, in complexes 2, 5, and 6, Ag­(I) ions mainly show N2-coordination geometry, ClO4 – and PF6 – are both not involved in coordination. The difference is attributed to the different coordination preferences and geometric shapes of TsO–, ClO4 –, and PF6 – anions. In complexes 3 and 4, NO3 – anions show strong coordination ability, and they coordinate to Ag­(I) ions in different modes.
elements.clean_text: Additionally, the different anions (TsO-, ClO4 -, PF6 -, and NO3 -) also play important roles in the formation of the diverse structures of the complexes. The difference in the coordinating ability, size, geometric shape, symmetry and hydrogen-bonding ability of anions is the underlying reason behind the differences in the structures of complexes. In complex 1, Ag(I) ions adopt distorted O2N2-coordination geometry. The TsO- anion, having strong coordinating ability, is involved in the coordinative interactions. At the same time, it also contributes to the formation of a higher-dimensional structure through the hydrogen bonding and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions based on it. However, in complexes 2, 5, and 6, Ag(I) ions mainly show N2-coordination geometry, ClO4 - and PF6 - are both not involved in coordination. The difference is attributed to the different coordination preferences and geometric shapes of TsO-, ClO4 -, and PF6 - anions. In complexes 3 and 4, NO3 - anions show strong coordination ability, and they coordinate to Ag(I) ions in different modes.

elements.content: Metal–organic complexes have been reported to have abilities to affect the emission wavelength and intensity of the organic material through metal coordination. Therefore, for potential applications as luminescent materials, the luminescent properties of ligands and complexes 1–6 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Figure presents the comparison of the emission spectra. L1 and L2 exhibit emission maximum at 516 and 511 nm, respectively, which are assigned to the π–π* transition. Compared to that of L1 or L2, the emission spectra of 1–6 are red-shifted to 521, 538, 535, 525, 569, and 521 nm, respectively. The obvious red shift for the emission bands in 1–6 with respect to that of the corresponding ligand is probably due to the formation of the supramolecular structures, and a possible assignment for the origin of the emission involves emissive states derived from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition. It is noteworthy that the remarkable red shift of 58 nm for the emission band is observed for 5, which may be attributed to the best plane and conjugation of the ligand in it, resulting in a smaller HOMO–LUMO gap. Additionally, except for 2, enhancement of the fluorescence intensities is realized in the other complexes. Obviously, the red shift and enhancement of the fluorescence intensities are considered to mainly arise from the coordination of metal atom to ligand. The incorporation of Ag­(I) may effectively increase the conformational rigidity of ligand and reduce the loss of energy via intramolecular vibrational and rotational motions. At the same time, the different anions and coordination environments of metal centers may also have an effect on the photoluminescence behaviors of the complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Property

Metal-organic complexes have been reported to have abilities to affect the emission wavelength and intensity of the organic material through metal coordination. Therefore, for potential applications as luminescent materials, the luminescent properties of ligands and complexes 1-6 have been investigated in the solid state at room temperature. Figure  presents the comparison of the emission spectra. L1 and L2 exhibit emission maximum at 516 and 511 nm, respectively, which are assigned to the π-π* transition. Compared to that of L1 or L2, the emission spectra of 1-6 are red-shifted to 521, 538, 535, 525, 569, and 521 nm, respectively. The obvious red shift for the emission bands in 1-6 with respect to that of the corresponding ligand is probably due to the formation of the supramolecular structures, and a possible assignment for the origin of the emission involves emissive states derived from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition. It is noteworthy that the remarkable red shift of 58 nm for the emission band is observed for 5, which may be attributed to the best plane and conjugation of the ligand in it, resulting in a smaller HOMO-LUMO gap. Additionally, except for 2, enhancement of the fluorescence intensities is realized in the other complexes. Obviously, the red shift and enhancement of the fluorescence intensities are considered to mainly arise from the coordination of metal atom to ligand. The incorporation of Ag(I) may effectively increase the conformational rigidity of ligand and reduce the loss of energy via intramolecular vibrational and rotational motions. At the same time, the different anions and coordination environments of metal centers may also have an effect on the photoluminescence behaviors of the complexes.

elements.content: To further understand the fluorescent properties, the fluorescence decay profiles of L1, L2, and complexes 1–6 were measured at their optimal excitation wavelengths in the solid state at room temperature. The results are shown in Figure S3, . The fluorescence lifetimes of L1 (0.09 ns) and L2 (<0.05 ns) are very short. However, the fluorescence lifetimes of complexes 1–6 are 0.27, 0.54, 0.47, 0.51, 3.63, and 0.48 ns, respectively, longer than that of corresponding ligand. From , we also find that complex 5 shows the longer fluorescence lifetime than other complexes. The increase in the decay times observed for all complexes may result from the less efficient nonradiative relaxation process due to the larger rigidity of the ligands in the coordination complexes.
elements.clean_text: To further understand the fluorescent properties, the fluorescence decay profiles of L1, L2, and complexes 1-6 were measured at their optimal excitation wavelengths in the solid state at room temperature. The results are shown in Figure S3, . The fluorescence lifetimes of  L1 (0.09 ns) and L2 (<0.05 ns) are very short. However, the fluorescence lifetimes of complexes 1-6 are 0.27, 0.54, 0.47, 0.51, 3.63, and 0.48 ns, respectively, longer than that of corresponding ligand. From , we also find that complex 5 shows the longer fluorescence lifetime than other complexes. The increase in the decay times observed for all complexes may result from the less efficient nonradiative relaxation process due to the larger rigidity of the ligands in the coordination complexes.

elements.content:
The results of the luminescent properties indicate that emission spectra of organic spacers L1 and L2 were remarkably affected by their incorporation into metal-containing coordination compounds.

Conclusions

Two multidentate ligands containing the pyridyl and dicyanoisophrone groups, 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-3-yl)-ethenyl]­cyclohex-2-enylidene}­propanedinitrile (L1) and 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-2-yl)-ethenyl]­cyclohex-2-enylidene}­propanedinitrile (L2), have been synthesized and used to construct a series of different structural Ag­(I) coordination polymers or discrete supramolecular complexes. Single crystal X-ray structures indicated that, in the six complexes, the ligands adopted several coordination modes to coordinate Ag­(I) ions, which play key roles in the formation of different supramolecular structures. Additionally, the different anions and solvents involved in also have an effect on the structures. The relationships between structures and luminescent properties were investigated. The red shift emission and enhancement of the fluorescence intensities were realized by coordination of Ag­(I) ions to ligands, indicating that metal–organic polymers have abilities to affect the emission wavelength, intensity, and lifetime of the organic material through metal coordination.

The results of the luminescent properties indicate that emission spectra of organic spacers L1 and L2 were remarkably affected by their incorporation into metal-containing coordination compounds.

Conclusions

Two multidentate ligands containing the pyridyl and dicyanoisophrone groups, 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-3-yl)-ethenyl]cyclohex-2-enylidene}propanedinitrile (L1) and 2-{5,5-dimethyl-3-[2-(pyridin-2-yl)-ethenyl]cyclohex-2-enylidene}propanedinitrile (L2), have been synthesized and used to construct a series of different structural Ag(I) coordination polymers or discrete supramolecular complexes. Single crystal X-ray structures indicated that, in the six complexes, the ligands adopted several coordination modes to coordinate Ag(I) ions, which play key roles in the formation of different supramolecular structures. Additionally, the different anions and solvents involved in also have an effect on the structures. The relationships between structures and luminescent properties were investigated. The red shift emission and enhancement of the fluorescence intensities were realized by coordination of Ag(I) ions to ligands, indicating that metal-organic polymers have abilities to affect the emission wavelength, intensity, and lifetime of the organic material through metal coordination.

All complexes were prepared by a similar procedure. A clear benzene solution (10 mL) of the silver salt AgX (1 mmol, X = TsO (1), ClO4 – (2 and 5), NO3 – (3 and 4), PF6 – (6)) was carefully layered onto a solution of L1 or L2 (0.276 g, 1 mmol) in dichloromethane (15 mL). Single crystals of 1–6 suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were obtained by slow interlayer diffusion.
